Got a kit, but the privacy concern is still nagging at me so I started to search for reviews and came across this, among other videos. This video actually made me really hesitant about consenting and sending my saliva in. Questions were softball and Destin went in like he's already part of the 23andme team, like he's there to debunk all your concerns, and not to find out if there is anything you should be concerned about. Many people brought up the fact that you actually gave them your entire DNA, but they're the one that chose not to use the entire thing. Destin showed how the saliva samples are tossed but not the digital info that they already logged in. He said Tara went and spoke with different researchers and professors all over the country and discussed the benefits and risks of doing this type of testing both on the individual level and its overall implications for society... but all that's shown in the video is her key takeaway, that optional questions are the key for scientists to find out what genotypes affect what traits, and they, as a family, want to contribute to the body of knowledge (5:41). At 12:49 she said she feels the benefits outweighs the risks (did not explain what the risks are), and that the information is helpful for the society as a whole as well as the individual. I feel like Tara's part is very weak, no actual discussion with researchers were shown, basically we'll just have to take her word for it. No wonder he had to say he didn't take money for this, because this does look like an ad for 23andme.

It’s not a clone that people are generally concerned about…it was the concern that they would start working with or handing data over to authorities and private entities such as medical insurance corporations. I say “was” because we have seen them do just this, so when someone tries to insure their child and finds out they can’t get covered or that it’s an outrageous cost; you might find it’s data given to these people by yourself or close relative that is to blame. It’s extremely naive or wilful ignorance to believe that them throwing out the sample means they destroy the data because it does not. In addition, authorities can of course step in and stop them from destroying it. It’s no conspiracy, it’s how law enforcement works.

Although Ancestry allow you to opt out of your DNA being submitted to research databases 'FOREVER',   they insist on using  your DNA  to develop commercial products. They are making a profit from using your DNA, and there is no way of opting out of this if you want to use an Ancestry DNA test.  The offending condition, non-negotiable, is in the kit activation process: "Ancestry may use my DNA data to create new products and services including products related to wellness and health". In my opinion Ancestry are being unethical by not allowing test kit users to opt out of this profiteering my Ancestry. For my part, as soon as my results are in I will delete my data from Ancestry.  They will have probably already copied it - why not be completely unethical, after all, if you are super focussed on making a profit?

Hi Destin,
I really appreciate how you approached this. But I must add this thought, though they may only "sequence" .2% of your data and return that to you, that does not mean that they "do not have all of your DNA". You are, in fact, giving them your entire gene sequence, however, they are choosing to only genotype .2%. Hence, the aversion for some of us. I understand the original sample can be discarded, but I want to know what they do with that electronic data. (I used to work in Molecular Genetics, just as an FYI for all of those comments nowadays that have concerns with people being educated in a field that they are not necessarily employed in.) Granted, perhaps they do fully discard it. But my concern is that if they don't, who's to say what it's used for. Additionally, there have already been instances where this data WAS used to find someone who had committed a crime. I'm not a criminal, but in a year or two when my conservative views are then considered criminal, who's to say someone can't use this in a nefarious way. Just putting this out there...

Re: comments about Windows XP/VIsta/7 running on their computers. I was an computer support person at a government research facility. I had to work with lots of 20-year old computers and operating systems, because that's what the lab equipment was designed to work with. Newer PC's wouldn't work with their equipment. Most equipment needs a very minimal computer anyway. It just instructs the machine to start doing its job, and collects the data. I'm sure analysis of the data is done somewhere else, but again, even a old PC can do that.

I remember an episode of "This Old House" where they toured a "state-of-the-art" facility that had a computer control a laser to maximize the number of pieces it could cut out of a sheet of steel with minimal waste. The sheets of steel were fed to a conveyor belt by a robotic arm, and the laser did it's cutting. Then they showed that the computerized laser was fed data by an old-style "ticker tape" with punched holes in it! That was a bit shocking even for me.
I’d live to hear about their generic COVID research.

okay, yes, they are only looking at 0.02% right now. look at the fine print. their terms of service allow them to keep your sample indefinitely. there is nothing stopping them from deciding to fully sequence your DNA in the future. not to mention only a small part of your genome is actually useful information, and there is a huge section of the human genome that is not only not unique to the individual, but not even unique to the human species. That's not a privacy selling point, that's just a point in favor of actually getting a medical test done instead, since you can learn a lot more that way.

here's the problem: we have medical genetic tests, ones that actually go way more in depth than any of these private companies, that are used in the healthcare setting. and what's nice about them, is that the maintenance of the privacy of the information of medical testing is mandated by law and closely protected. the same is not true for these private companies.

How the samples are handled is not the really interesting part of privacy (and security). What you want to know is how the DATA that gets generated from those samples is handled. To really understand THAT, you'd have to dig into what goes on at 23andMe, not so much Labcorp.
Ideally, the only person who has an unencrypted copy of that data is YOU (and the only one with the decryption key is also you) but it sounds like that is not how this works. Then, the main thing that you need to worry about is that Labcorp well and truly destroys the initial pre-encrypted data, not just the sample.

DNA testing is one of most tricky pieces of the new medical puzzle right now. Real medical decisions can be made from these kinds of tests. One of the most common is the risk for a woman to develop ovarian cancer. Yes... knowing this risk is great! The issue comes in is what is done with this information. If you have XYZ genetic markers, would an insurance company refuse to cover you, or charge you obnoxious premiums simply because you have a marker that increased your risk of X? What other decisions can be made if your genetic markers display other things? Having been in the lab industry, I've been a part of many conversations about just how dangerously deep that information COULD be used (everything from prenatal decision making to excluding populations of people because of one genetic trait). It's a huge ethical question mark in the medical world right now and one we need to be cautious of.

The issue isn't that "23 and me" will sell the data (I mean, they could, but that's frankly not the high risk here). The privacy issue is that this information legally constitutes medical records - which is why you had to use a HIPAA warning as well. By US law, life insurance companies are entitled to a portion of that information, depending on individual state laws, and you have to provide it if you have it and your state allows companies to collect it. This doesn't directly impact other forms of insurance, but it does create a conflict of interest which many of us are concerned about where information gathering and data processing begins quietly connecting the dots behind the scenes. For example, suppose my brother takes a test in a state that allows it to be collected and his employer-provided life insurance policy collects it. There is nothing in place other than laws without actual enforcement to prevent it being connected to his health insurance records, which already contain information connected to his family health. This isn't a slippery slope, it's something we've seen done in other industries with access to this level of connecting data. Even if the companies aren't so unscrupulous as to violate data laws, that doesn't prevent it from being swept up in AI pattern processes. Less data than this has had companies marketing diapers to people who didn't even know they were pregnant yet.


While I agree that DNA testing has a lot of potential for the future of humanity, we have a very burdensome lead weight around our collective necks right now in the form of an insurance industry that decides far too much of our fate. Until we remove that lead weight, we need to be careful where we swim.

I did my DNA through Ancestry and then ran it through a health program called Prometheuse.  I did it because everyone in my family dies of cancer, and I wanted to see if it said I was genetically predisposed.  Well, guess what?  It came back and said I have the BRCA-1 gene mutation, the gene that gives you a 70% chance of breast cancer and 40% chance of ovarian cancer and a high risk of other cancers.  I was so upset.  I grieved, I obsessively researched, I cried.... it was terrible.  Then I went to my gynecologist to discuss my options.  She redid the test just to be sure, and 2 months later.... it came back negative.  Turns out I never had the BRCA-1 gene mutation; Prometheuse just told me I did. I come from a rough and tumble family of extremes. While there are some exceptions we tend to produce a few archetypes which are common enough to call 'normal.' We are a family that produces literally tons of males - lots and lots of 'It's a Boy!' memorabilia. We produce military men, cops, crooks, and construction workers. It is safe to say this accounts for 75% of our makeup.

Recently a case in the neighboring county involved a person doing their DNA profile and then this profile leading to the arrest of a family member who had committed a murder which had been unsolved to that point (Raymond Rowe aka DJ Freeze and the murder of Christy Mirack).

I wound up one of the ones who joined the military and then got into construction. While my relationship with many of my family members is strained due to the prevalence of crooks, they are still my family. I am torn between whether it would simply be a case of one getting their rightful justice or whether I would be risking a family schism that would forever change the tenuous balance we have achieved if I did one of these tests and it implicated a family member. Destin, thanks so much for the video. As always, I really enjoy and live through your curiosity. I marvel at your work and am a big fan. I've even reposted you videos to my nerd friends on LinkedIn - who enjoyed the posts.

Let me point out that my heritable traits are passed by genetic and epigenetic material. Epigenetic material is relatively recently discovered and all the possible interactions between genetic and epigenetic material is still ambiguous/unknown at best. In this vein, there's bound to be more cellular or even molecular substance that suport trait heritability yet to be discovered (such discovery happens regularly as you may suspect).

The medical (legal, financial) implications have only been recently been evaluated. I could go on a long dialog about the information interaction between genetic and epigenetic materials but I'm more concerned that this analysis - and now your video - doesn't really reflect the deeper complexity of interaction. I expect that this process is just beginning of discovering heritable materials in the cell much less heritable "interchange" materials that communicate and are communicated between cells.

The biggest privacy concern (which your video describes as "handling" but not information sharing) is that heritable defects can be used against someone if say a risk management entity (like say an insurance company) or a financial entity (say a credit bureau or bank or VISA) gets the defect information and decides to make a judgement call of "risk" based on only the genetic material not the epigenetic material or the interaction between these two molecules (by suppression or amplification of "traits"/defects). Information sharing of my genetic material may be patented by a company and I receive no compensation (isn't that theft?). Of course these comments may be just be paranoid - I didn't get enough sleep last night - but it seems to me to be a logical concern.

I realize this may be a stretch but as a fan and a happy subscriber to your youtube channel (sorry, I'm cheap...), I felt compelled to point this all out. I've read some of the other comments but didn't really see much discussion I could agree with...

It seems as though Lab Corp is doing their due diligence based on destruction requests. 23 and Me does not allow kits to be registered anonymously, and they also appear to maintain your results with your contact information indefinitely. They do not appear to accept requests for destruction of result data after its provided to the customer, and I could not find a data retention policy for result data. Allowing anonymous kits to be ordered, or honoring a request to destroy the result data after delivery to a customer, would provide additional protections to customer in the event of a data breach or subpoena from the courts. If no backup copy of the data exists, then it can not be accessed again later. If anonymity where available, then the data could still be used to benefit the greater good while providing additional protections for customers.

In the end, Lab Corp isn't going to clone you with your left over spit, but 23 and Me seems maintain your results indefinitely, and I suspect when you order a Genealogy test, they pay Lab Corp to run the Health + Ancestry test, although I'm speculating on this one. Why does this matter? Well if your result data is exposed at 23 and Me for whatever reason, its likely that more than Genealogy data will be exposed even though that may be all you've ordered.

Over all its an interesting video, thanks for your hard work.

Privacy IS an issue because the tests do not allow for anonymity.  Setting aside the shipping address, the only billing options are Paypal and credit card.  Both leave an identifiable digital footprint. Further, the data is stored permanently (whether the physical sample is or not) and can be vulnerable, now or in the future, to hackers, employers, health insurers, and the US government's Combined DNA Index System (CODIS).  I know that not many people take privacy seriously anyway, but these companies could include bitcoin and/or cash payments options, and the ability to pick up kits (stocked or pre-ordered) at someplace like affiliated drug stores and pharmacies.  But I'm sure that's not practical simply to cater to a niche portion of the market  :)

I completely understand the desire for privacy, especially from the same governing powers that have been tied to suppressed technologies (fuels, electric/power, quantum computers, etc), deception (to gain support for wars, to distract & hide, etc), and the list goes on. Control is power, as well with knowledge. Political leaders are seemingly always caught up in scandals and lies, while the well-being of society is sometimes overlooked, sabotaged, or purposefully mislead so the powers at be can retain and/or grow their positions. I think most educated individuals would agree I'm not even touching base on any conspiracy theories, outlandish claims, or questionable heresy.
That being said, even if a reputable company like 23&me is transparent with their intentions, operating entirely within the laws, and focusing a great deal of investment towards security and the privacy of their customers, it might make all the gathered data (DNA, genomes, ancestral, etc) difficult for an outside threat to obtain, but certainly not impossible. There are different levels of technology, weapons, information, etc, available to the public, than what a governmental agency has full access to. For example; I can go out tomorrow and purchase a firearm fairly easily, but for me to acquire a rocket launcher.. well, that's not going to happen, at least not while abiding by all state and federal laws. BUT, if we use an example from a higher level of [authority], our military can purchase rocket launchers in bulk. Now, if we keep going up levels we'll find more exclusivity and eventually reach examples of highly advanced technological innovation only available/known to the most elite.. whether that be small/secretive sectors of agencies like the Secret Service, CIA, NSA, FBI, or even some off-the-books privately funded battalion of hyper-advanced masterminds.. Most likely there's already an existing quantum-powered hacking server so far beyond anything that will be acknowledged/released publicly for decades past our grandchildren.
Truthfully, every ounce of our privacy and [freedom] could be stripped away by next week. Thankfully, as far as we know, that's unlikely. It's good to be prepared to an extent, but it can quickly become counterproductive to constantly overlook the present for fear of what the near future might bring.
In conclusion.. If you're posting your vehicle For Sale online, make sure to blur out your license plate in the pics! I've never heard of a single bad thing actually occurring because a publicly-displayed plate was visibly posted online, but come on.. IT'S NOT WORTH THE RISK!

I think these types of services could be very, very useful for individuals with genetic conditions if tweaked to cater to a more medical field. Geneticist appointments can be very expensive and difficult to come by. I would just hope that it never becomes standard practice until we can handle that sort of information.

For example I have a genetic connective tissue disorder of some type, that much is clear. My doctors are also convinced I have, more specifically, Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome(most likely hypermobile type, hEDS given my history). We aren't pursuing a confirmation from a geneticist for several reasons, though. Some of it is clinical in nature, the diagnosis isn't required for proper treatment/monitoring & the condition is relatively unknown enough that future doctors may not know what it means in an emergency anyway. It would, clinically speaking, have minimal impact compared to just listing my symptoms and being on top of monitoring my health.

Other parts are practical in nature: a genetic work-up to rule out other forms of Ehlers-Danlos with known markers, alongside a clinical opinion from a geneticist confirming hEDS, would be thousands of dollars(and not covered by insurance) and feature a waiting list of 6+ months. This is where a more medical-grade version of services like 23 & Me could step in and help my physiatrist confirm the exact diagnosis himself, with little hassle and cost .

However, this leads into yet MORE practical concerns that have informed my healthcare team's opinion: with healthcare reform up in the air and current protections in question, an hEDS diagnosis could become a MASSIVE pre-existing condition if those come back at all. Plus, going back to the lack of knowledge out there overly-cautious or underinformed doctors may only know about the rarest and grossest forms of the condition which render the label not just useless, but actively reinforcing improper care due to ignorance. I have an important, but not strictly necessary, surgery I am looking forward to in a few years; if I had hEDS on my record I could be denied it due to the surgeon googling it and finding horror stories about EDS fragility & healing problems(which aren't terrible pronounced in me, the only issue is scars last a long time).

Thus there are specific advantages, at the moment at least, to not having that specific label on my health records! It's at best neutral to my health care, and worst cast scenario could be detrimental. I wouldn't want to have a catch-all screener that confirmed a form of EDS being made a part of standard medical procedure, until those concerns were all eliminated as well.

While this technology could be really useful in giving people more accessible avenues to learn about their own genes and genetic conditions, it absolutely needs to be balanced with caution & restraint given the deeply flawed nature of our healthcare systems.

Great video as always man. I think most people don't understand how the medical reference laboratory business works and can't blame them. But for those who don't know, it's a high volume industry. I work for another lab and my department is one that basically sorts the samples to go to the testing departments. We accession something like 30,000 to 50,000 samples PER DAY at just our one facility.

HIPAA regulations are super strict about patient information privacy. The fact that Labcorp let you into their facility WITH A CAMERA TO POST ON YOUTUBE is actually more mind blowing than I think people can understand. They must have sanitized all the areas of actual samples beforehand. Even within our facility we are not allowed to have any cameras. Even if it's in the course of doing one's job it has to be done by people on a very short approved list, and only then if the frame will have ZERO PHI (patient health info), in the frame. Or, if for whatever reason a pic needs to be taken of a specific vial or manifest it has to again be done by someone who is trusted and approved to do so. Even our humble positions are required to be up to date every year with HIPAA regs in order to maintain employment with the company. While I can't speak for every lab, I'm pretty sure all such labs in our country follow the same HIPAA guidelines.

Notice the lack of people in the departments. Notice how there wasn't a bunch of work being done? I'm going out on a guess here but I'm pretty sure most of those people (not counting the UPS guy lol), were managers or at least group leaders. Notice how everyone was on pins and needles? Watch their body language....nervous, hesitant. Because here's a guy with a video camera in the lab!!

It's actually pretty awesome, people just don't realize how strict HIPAA regs are. To the point that I'm going to guess every vial you saw was an empty with a blank test label on it just in order to show the process.

As to people all bent out of shape over privacy. Guys, there's no way to even use that info. It isn't a sci-fi book were they can use it to track you down or somehow encrypt or decrypt things with it. Even IF somehow a shady government or public agency got the info, what are they getting? Oh right, the insurance thing right right.....so, how's that different than someone telling them they smoke before they get insurance? How's it different than telling them you have three drinks a day? Or that you have a couple of people in your family that died of cancer of a certain type??? It isn't. But this is all what-if and let's weigh the up and down side. So an insurance company in our what-if can glean that you are predisposed to a certain kind of cancer or other medical issue. The flip side is your doctor can also get said results and say "omg hey you have a big chance to get <some random ailment> so we should do some tests!"

Potentially saving my life........paying a higher premium.....hmm

Honestly, get a hobby already. All the mental horsepower put into conspiracy theories could have gotten us to Alpha Centauri by now!!

If you purchased a PGS, "Personal Genome Service", from 23andMe.com from October 16, 2007, to November 22, 2013, you are included in a settlement and may receive cash compensation. On January 13, 2014, the putative class action arbitration captioned Davis-Hudson, et al. v. 23andMe, Inc. was submitted to the American Arbitration Association and assigned Case No. 74-20-1400-0032 (the “Arbitration”). The claims asserted in the Arbitration arose out of the Warning Letter and concerned 23andMe’s PGS. The reason they only need 0.02% of your DNA is because that's the stuff that varies from human to human. All humans share 99.98% identical DNA. The reason they only work with that 0.02% is just for minimizing file sizes by focusing only on the variable parts. That 0.02% contains all the relevant information anyone with sufficient technology would need to know everything about your genetics.

It's just a matter of file formatting. It's like if you're giving directions to someone. You don't give every single turn along the way. You just say "you know how to get downtown from here? Okay. Do that, but take a left instead of a right on Sycamore." Or "you know what a generic reference human genome looks like? Okay, do that, but these 600,000 sites are different."

Thanks for the video, but I'm not sure it resolves many concerns people have about 23andMe. For example, while they claim to only test 600k locations (called SNPs, or single nucleotide polymorphism) rather than sequencing the entire genome, they still get your entire genome. It's not like you only send in 600k of your base pairs through the mail. And also, the interesting and unique genetic information about you as a person comprises only a tiny fraction of your total DNA sequence.

Second, while I believe that Destin is totally sincere in his belief that privacy is secure, countless companies from Equifax to Ashley Madison have assured their customers of the same. Plus, as others have correctly pointed out, once the genotyping is complete, the physical sample is irrelevant. It's the digital data that's important. Who cares what happens to the actual vials?

But most notable is the fact that medical science just doesn't yet know enough to translate data from thousands of SNPs to accurately predict disease risk in individual patients. There are currently too many unknowns. Plus, few doctors truly understand how to make use of this information in medical decision-making, let alone laypeople. Between the uncertainty and cognitive phenomena like loss aversion, results from 23andMe are just as likely to lead a person to making an illogical life decision as a logical one. And the field of pharmacogenomics (i.e. using genotyping to guide drug selection) is in its infancy, and probably a generation away from real life clinical application in all but a few, narrow situations (e.g. choosing chemotherapy based on genotyping of certain tumors).

Bottom line: This is fascinating from a medical research standpoint, and may be an integral part of healthcare in 25-50 years. But today, in 2017, it's probably not worth your money (or privacy risk).

I think it's also important to emphasize that the results are based on correlations between self-report survey data, and sequence data. There is little causal data to support the link between a specific genotype and that genotype being causally related to a health risk factor, or an ancestry location. Indeed the more data there is, the more confident that correlation becomes, but I think people still assume that "if this comes back saying I'm 30% Irish, it's because I have 'Irish DNA'", or if it comes back saying 'i have a risk factor associated with Parkinson's disease', then this genotype 'causes Parkinson's' disease." The correlative data does not, as I understand it, mean we can make statements like that.

I think that's what you mean by saying "know what this does NOT mean", but I think as a figure with a public voice it's important to discuss this nuance.

23andMe may be providing customers with gentotypes, but 23andMe could still use the DNA for genome sequencing if they ever wanted to. I'm still glad that Smarter Every Day was able to produce this content, but let's not kid ourselves. It's like when people claim that Google is just a search engine without recognizing just how much information Google can access from individuals.
Also, the fact they sponsored this video, makes me question the transparency

The 0.02% thing seems a little bit of a misleading statistic. While it is true that is the overall percentage of your DNA, it is slightly misleading in that its not necessarily the percentage of your DNA that matters. Consider how much of our DNA is shared with a Banana (~50%) or a chimpanzee (~99%). Then consider that a not insignificant portion of our DNA is considered to be non-coding or junk DNA.

All that put together could make the percentage of your DNA that they are testing for out of your total DNA that matters a good bit larger. I am far enough from an expert to not know even within orders of magnitude what that final percentage would be, but it would almost certainly be higher than the 0.02% stated.

That said, that doesn't scare me off of testing services like 23&me so much as not seeing it as a good value at its current price.

Unfortunately, there's still some uncertainty around the legal implications of knowing various genetic testing results. To their credit, they clearly outline the risks in their Terms of Service:

"While the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act was signed into law in the United States in 2008, its protection against discrimination by employers and health insurance companies for employment and coverage issues has not been clearly established. In addition, GINA does not cover life, long-term care, or disability insurance providers." ... "If you are asked by an insurance company whether you have learned Genetic Information about health conditions and you do not disclose this to them, this may be considered to be fraud."

Yikes!

It's also unclear how much information they associate with your account. They definitely ask for your full name and date of birth, although I suppose you do not have to provide real details. I do wonder if they store the address a particular barcoded tube was shipped to, which is harder to conceal if you are concerned about your privacy. They do sell kits in stores, but you still have to pay a separate lab fee through their website when you submit your sample, making it hard to have a truly anonymous 23andme account.

The bit about .02% of your DNA being analyzed is a bit misleading. If you go back and look at that bookshelf, there is a binder labelled "exome," which contains only the coding regions of DNA, and accounts for about 1% of human DNA. 0.02% is still a lot smaller than 1%, but the vast majority of your DNA is identical to others (even other animals), so a relatively small number of SNPs could tell you a lot about a person.

I am also curious about what kind of data they give you if you are truly curious. The FDA has finally allowed them to disclose some health information, but there are certain categories of health information that they cannot give out. However, I have heard that you can download the raw SNP data and interpret the results yourself?

If you are actually concerned about privacy, what happens to the sample is only the first question you should ask. What should concern you more is data - the data they extract from the sample AND the data that is connected to your account (like payment data, ip address, email address, etc...). Who owns it, and who controls access to it? As long as there is a trail connecting that sample number to your account info, it's not really anonymous.

Perhaps most importantly, you need to ask yourself - how does this company make money? According to Wikipedia, the company has raised over $240 million in venture funding - that's money that investors expect to see a return on. Yet as of October 2015 they had not turned a profit. That means that there will be methods of monitization implemented in the future that are not implemented right now. It costs them significantly more than $199 to process your sample. That means their business model is not going to be based on selling you information about your own genes. Rather, it's going to be based on selling information about your genes to someone else (probably multiple someones). Who those someone elses are is not yet clear, and may never be, but it's going to have to be someone who's willing to pay enough to make up the difference in cost, and then some. Google was one big investor in 23andme. How difficult would it be for them to connect you to your sample if they are a buyer? If you log into 23andme with a gmail account, then not hard at all.

Do you get to control what information they sell, and to whom? Or do they make you sign something that gives them the freedom to make those decisions without consulting or notifying you?

Do they have the freedom at any time to change the policies that govern access to your information without your explicit opt-in?

If you don't get fine-grained control over who they can share the information with, then you don't have control over your own privacy, or even know how your privacy might be impacted.

And this is to say nothing of hackers, subpoenas, leaks, etc...

In conclusion - thanks for showing us the lab - it's always cool to see what technology actually looks like in practice. And I enjoyed seeing the chips and getting a bit of an explanation as to how they work. Even though I think you're going way too far by saying "I no longer have privacy concerns" I do really appreciate that thanks to you I have a little bit more information than I did before.

Woah woah woah... Transparent and unbiased? That should raise a red flag. Nothing is ever unbiased. First of all, whether or not Destin makes a favorable or unfavorable video about 23andme, just the fact that he is featuring them is a form of advertisement. It brings the company to the awareness of people who did not know about it, who will then make their own opinions. "any publicity is good publicity" right. Second, lets not forget that Destin is being REWARDED financially by 23andme. Destin can say what he wants, but he's only human, and humans like rewards and act to reinforce them. I thought the questions that Destin asked were very "safe" and not particularly deep or technical.
Destin interviews a man who says he is not related to 23andme. Really? Is Labcor not a customer of 23andme? Does 23andme not pay Labcor large sums of money for their service? How do you think Labcor's profit would be affected if they said something negative about a customer of theirs.
Let's also not forget that both 23andme and Labcor are US companies. We already know the US government has backdoors to various tech companies, and engages in untargeted, mass, secret spying. We know the government is corruptible. Do you think these companies would talk about classified stuff like that on a Youtube channel? We also know that large companies and governments get hacked, and data is stolen, fairly frequently.
If you do offer them your genetic data, is it going to help humanity? Probably... depending who is using it. But it's a double edged sword, and there is certainly opportunity for abuse. You better believe that there will be practices with questionable ethics happening in the future. Once powerful people know the genetic makeup of an entire city (or more), it will be much easier to exploit the population with policy engineered towards certain physical or psychological traits.
I'm not saying people should not use 23andme, or that we should be paranoid about it. It's a brave new world we have to navigate. But let's be completely honest and balanced when we're talking about it, so we can avoid the pitfalls. Sorry, but this was a shameless shill video.

My family is benefitting from this technology in a very tangible way. We have Lynch Syndrome in our family, which makes you much more likely to develop bowel cancers. If I understand correctly, one person had their genes sequenced and scientists found where the mutation is. Now all the people in my family have to do is get a blood test, and the scientists know exactly where to look to see whether we have that syndrome or not. My mum was first to be tested and she has it, so she already knows my siblings and I each have a 50/50 shot. My sister found out at age 18 that she has the syndrome, so she can now manage other risk factors in her life and get regular and early screening tests. I don't have it, so I don't have to waste health resources getting stacks of screenings done for a condition I'm no more likely to develop than Joe Blogs. I also know my children won't have it. We haven't convinced my brother to have the testing yet. My testing was not done by a private company and they only looked for this one condition, so it's quite different from 23andMe. I had my testing done my a genetics lab in Australia after getting a referral from my doctor. I had to go to a genetics councillor to have the test and the possible results explained to me. It was explained what the results (positive or negative) would mean and what my risks were for developing bowel cancer if we assumed a positive result. We even got my family tree out as part of the counselling! All of this was explained before I was allowed to sign the consent form for the blood test. It was a really good way to have the testing done. The councillor and a doctor were there when I got my results as well, which would have been particularly helpful for my sister, who got 'bad' news.

As someone who works in this field, let me just point out that while you're correct that you're "only" giving them 0.02% of your DNA sequence, it's the most informative (as far as we currently know) 0.02%. Sure, you're leaving out 99.98% of your DNA, but that 99.98% doesn't have the information 23andme needs to get your ancestry and health information. You might be giving them a low proportion of your DNA, but the information in that 0.02% far outweighs what a tiny fraction of raw sequence it actually is. In other words, "it's only 0.02% of your total DNA!" does NOT translate to "you're not giving them much of your genetic information." I could learn a great deal about you that you may not want me to know from that "only" 0.02%. For what it's worth, as curious as I am about my own genetic info, I still refuse to do 23andme because the legal regulations to protect that information simply do not exist yet. This technology is too new for our protections to have caught up with it.

I worked as a bioinformatics tech for a bit while in college a few years ago, and believe me, the scale of the data we had to work with was simply absurd. We had a 64 core dedicated processor for running sequencing, sorting and search algorithms on the mountains of genetic data we had to deal with, and even then, any script that we ran that wasn't totally optimized to run in n^2 time or less would still take days to fully execute. In the same room as our workstations was the campus Illumina HiSeq machines. Seeing all of that really brought me back.

Now that I mention it, Destin, I think you'd be pretty fascinated to see that end of the workflow as well. I mean, we do just sit on our butts and type code all day, but its still a lesser known part of the process.

I used the https://genographic.nationalgeographic.com/ tests instead as I trust their double-blind registration and results process.

Something similar to this service that is free is the Genes for good research project by the University of Michigan (just google it). You take a certain number of health surveys and then qualify to opt-in to provide a DNA spit sample. The University of Michigan gets to see if there are correlations between certain answers to the health surveys and DNA from the population that participated and you get your ancestry and the raw data. So, you don't get as much information as you would from 23andMe but because you have your raw data you could utilize outside sources to see what you can find out on your own AND you're contributing valuable information to the research project.

Genotyping might only test .02% of your genome, but it's testing SNPs associated with population and phenotype variation as well as various health trait. Much of the >99% they don't test is that which isn't really different person to person. What they do test is that which varies, and the sum total of all of those varying nucleotides over 500-900 thousand locations, even removing the lower confidence ones and any no-calls, is still plenty sufficient to identify that genotype data with you if you were to be re-tested. With 23andme, it seems that they're largely transparent about what they do with your data, and allow you plenty of opportunity to give or deny consent for the use of your data in cohort studies. However, no matter how good their intentions may be, there are other people and organizations who may have less well meaning designs on that data, and will try to get at it. Everything from federal alphabet agencies, to health insurance companies, and if you think they're just not going to try and hack that data out of ethical principle, you're naive. If they can, and if they think they can get away with it, they will.

Here's the thing, you're saying you're not giving up all of your genomic info BUT:
1. There's nothing preventing them from actually sequencing your genome, this is currently quite the stretch given it's still pretty expensive (those long term storage guys might be in for a surprise in a few years) that's probably the reason they offer that option, so they have a nice varied supply of genomic data to sequence once it becomes economically viable.)
2. Those markers are, at the moment, the actual interesting thing, hence 23andme can give you that info with only those. You realise that's the exact thing you were afraid of when you thought they had your genome? That they might sell off that information to insurance companies and such?

Of course their labs are well organised, it's genotyping, they have to be or the result will fail. Besides, the lab doesn't have your name, 23andme on the other hand has everything. It's the whole business aspect of having you're genomic data that's the worrying part. What is 23andMe allowed to do with your sample/data? What is the lab allowed to do when your sample is in long term storage? Do they share the outcomes with third party, or even keep it themselves? Are they even tied to established medical laws?
It's the whole business model of 23andMe that should interest you, not how they treat their samples (for now).

Of course they are going to use genotyping! It would be pointless to get an analysis of your entire genome, this is because humans share over 99% of our DNA. I must say that we know not nearly enough about human genetics to say what a single allele's effect in the whole system of DNA means/does. We know that for some alleles, but not to nearly the amount that 23andme wants you to think. I think this is very problematic, not from a data privacy standpoint, but from a scientific standpoint. In other words: we have become really good in sequencing large amounts of DNA in a short period of time, but we barely understand what the code pieces in the context of the whole animal means. Additionally, barely anyone who gets these results is able to understand what they mean. They just see "higher probability for disease X", so therefore I get disease X. And I don't mean this arrogantly, I wouldn't be able to either if I had not done a master's degree in evolutionary biology. Really problematic video, they did not talk about the situation even remotely critically enough. It's been a long time since I unliked a video of this channel.

Destin, thanks for the work but I think you did not investigate a very important part. Even though 23 and Me does not get the full genome, the 0.02% they get is sufficient to be a privacy concern since they can match it directly to the spitter. If they cannot match it to a person then they should tell you, "You are one of 'x' people with that same genome," when they send a report or later when a match is found. You may have found an organ donor.

The privacy question is, "Who gets that genotype information besides the owner of the genotype?" LabCorp isn't the primary privacy issue as they only have a number. Of course this begs the question if they have gathered any other information that does not go to 23 and Me and even if the spit is destroyed, is the raw data they collected?

Does 23 and Me sell or in any way give up your personally identifiable information with your genetic information to others and if so, under what circumstances? Can your insurance company get access to it? Even though I might never get a disease due to the non-coding parts of my sequence blocking that gene's being expressed, if some company thinks I might get it, my health insurance could deny coverage as a "pre-existing condition" or radically raise rates because of the supposed financial risk to them. Possibly worse, my life insurance company may refuse to pay my beneficiaries because I did not divulge that information when I signed up for a policy.

When I first heard about 23 and Me I sent a note through their website asking this very question. They never responded.

Hey Destin, I think you might have accidentally misled the audience here by saying that ONLY 0.02% of our genetic code is sequenced as if that makes it better.
However, only 1% of our DNA codes for genes (the rest is 'junk DNA') and our genes only a small percentage of the base pairs are different between individuals. In reality then, if you want to be able to tell the genetic differences between people or what it is that makes them unique, all you really need is 0.02% i.e. the most valuable part.

I'd sure like to know more about how the genetic information determines ancestry data. How do they know what markers correspond to what population group? Where did they get that information? At what point in time was that information relevant, and have population shifts since then changed the meaning behind the names we use for ethnicities? How accurate is the matching of genetic markers to population groups? What markers are more and less reliable than others? Are there ancestral data for which they cannot test? How many of your ancestors are detected by the profiling?

It's not just privacy! The licensing is the major concern!! Michael Crichton even wrote his last book ("Next") about the potential problems with this business model. It's hardly an example of literary excellence, but it does raise very important questions that should have been considered before making this video, or submitting a sample. In addition to the potential for "designer" genetic manipulation, which is also discussed in the book, there's the arguably larger problem of signing away your rights to your own sequence and any cell lines, tests, procedures, or treatments that may be developed from the sample you send. They can develop a treatment for a disease that you don't even know you have yet, based on what they learn and develop from your own cells and genetic code, and you not only won't have any rights to the profits from that treatment, but you will have to pay whatever crazy sums they want to charge if you need that treatment. In other words, they shouldn't be charging you for this service, they should be paying you!!

Seriously, look it up. It's right on their site (and on the sites of their competitors). But it's not in the privacy agreement, it's a separate agreement so most people don't find it when they take the time to read any of the terms. By submitting your sample you grant to them irrevocable, transferable rights (meaning they can sell it to another party with their own motives and terms) to ANYTHING that comes from your sample. That is the single most broad license I've ever heard of. Something 1/1000th as severe would be considered terrible for a copyright license, and this is far more significant than copyright.

Destin, I love your videos, but I'm afraid you've done a disservice here by not covering this side of their business model. Please consider taking this video down, doing the relevant research (by all means, don't take my word for it), adding your findings in, and republishing it. There's a reason investors are pumping so much cash into these businesses, and it has nothing to do with the health and ancestry of the people submitting their samples. It's WAY bigger than that.

It is important to understand that the genotype collection is on the basis of RELEVANT genetic sequences. A genome, even in highly intelligent beings such as humans, has an incredible amount of noncoding base pairs as well as tandem repeats. These pieces of the DNA do not code for any protein and are popularly thought to serve as a means of spacing out the extremely important parts of the genome; this is what 23 and me is not including in your genotype. What they do have, however, is all of the important regions which code for what makes you, well you.

There are also highly conserved regions within our DNA which code for things that many different species would want since they are desirable traits. Traits like having a cell nucleus and how they are packaged, transported, stored, and simply function are processes that many organisms use. We have an exact match with 99.9 percent of any other given human, yet how are we so different? I'm mean, hell, we have a 98 percent match with chimpanzees, a 85 percent match mice, and even a banana matches perfectly with 60 percent of our genome. So many organisms have parts of their genome nearly identical to other species. 23 and me is not concerned with these segments either.

What you are giving them in that 90 sheets of paper is that extremely important 0.01 percent of your DNA that essentially reveals everything about you. It sounds glamorous to say we only give them a tiny fraction of our sequence, but this is literally everything some people want to be private. We are essentially giving them a mansion filled with packing peanuts and garbage, but there is a diamond buried within the house. The only valuable part is the diamond, and this is what they take and leave you with the house.

I don't want this to go without saying that I love you videos and that I am a loyal subscriber. I also feel that people have the right to understand what they are actually sending off when they use this service since their genotype is now on file forever.

Destin, I really loved this episode of smarter every day since I am a biomedical scientist and I do understand what the 23andme test can tell you about your health and what it can not. However, I felt that you missed out in this video to explain this a little bit more deeper since this is the core of the problem with these genotyping tests; one cannot test all of the different SNPs sicne there are a lot of them. 23andme just tests for the most common ones and thus cannot provide for a full picture for your health risk. Yes, it might be that one has a SNP that increases the risk of heart failure which comes out of the test, however it might also be that you have another 3 SNPs that decreases the risk of heart failure which are not tested by 23andme (since these are "rare" SNPs). Therefore it is very difficult to make these risk assesments and I kinda missed this message in your video.

Anyway, keep up the good work! I really love your videos and you do a great job with them in making people interested in science. There should really be more people like you that are just curious about how the world works!

I've got a BSc in Genetics so thought I'd explain a bit more on how significant that small percentage of DNA they take is and also add some extra interesting facts, including why we're still not really using genetics much in medicine (which I believe ties into the third party scientists mention of the "nuances of human genetics"). :)

Firstly, while I'm not paranoid about it, what they mentioned on genotyping and how little info they take - that small percentage is actually not as safe and insignificant as you might imagine. This is because the vast majority of your DNA is made of repetitive "non-coding" sequences. As an example one single type of repetitive sequence, called the ALU sequence, makes up about 10% of your DNA - this is more than all the "coding" elements put together! When you look at how much of your DNA is coding data it's actually a very small amount, so they'd actually be collecting a substantial amount of info on what makes you uniquely you, and this could still be used to identify you! While I say this though, the interesting fact is that in things like paternity tests, they actually don't use any coding data! They use the pattern of the non-coding elements - so in a paternity test they ironically identify the father from DNA that doesn't specifically code for the father or the child!

You may be wondering why there's so much non-coding DNA - interestingly they used to call this "junk DNA" as they knew it didn't make proteins and thought it was waste left over from evolution. They actually used to remove this on early cloned animals, but through that they realised it's not actually "junk" (if you look up Dolly the sheep, one reason she actually got really ill because they removed her "junk" DNA). This is actually used - amongst other things - to promote/inhibit/control what parts of the genome are expressed. This is known as epigenetics (which also has a lot of other areas, not just this - it's truly fascinating!), and that's one of the new big areas of genetic research. With epigenetics, we now know that even the coding parts don't specifically code for who you are as there are further controls and some of it is never even used! That is why for most genes they don't say "You have X gene so you'll get X illness" - they only say a % as your body may or may not use those genes in ways that cause that illness. ...also this is different for every cell in the body as they're all pretty much independent.

If you want to read anything even more fascinating you should look into the human microbiome - which is how they actually think the DNA of organisms inhabiting out body could have even more impact on things like health than our own genome through (genetic) symbiosis! The total bacteria inside you have potentially 100s of times more genetics data that you do, so if there is symbiosis there you can get how relevant that is - essentially they're an extension of your genome! ...worth remembering that next time you're prescribed a broad spectrum antibiotic (which basically aims to kill all internal bacteria!!). With epigenetics and the human microbiome though, hopefully that shows why so little genetic info is still used in medicine and diagnostics. DNA is not the simple blueprint of life we thought it was 20-30 years ago, so it's not a straight tool that can be used for diagnosis - it more shows you potentially how healthy or sick you could be, rather than what you will be.

I was concerned about what actually happens with my genetic information when submitted to 23andMe, so when they approached me and asked me if I wanted to make a video I decided to investigate it top to bottom.  Visiting the Lab and learning that their data is contractually isolated from the sample and the fact that it's not the entire DNA sequence being sent to 23andMe headquarters passed my smell test and satisfied my privacy concerns.  My wife spoke with professors and industry leaders from around the country and learned about the benefits of a future of medicine based on genomics.  My wife, Dr. Lamb, and 23andMe all independently stressed the importance of understanding exactly what the results of the health genotype testing mean by consulting your (well informed) doctor.  In a nutshell, the results don't provide deterministic results, but a probablistic indicator based on historical data.  Many other factors play a huge role in how your body works.
